title: CR-10 Dial Holder Bracket Mount - larger diameter

description.text:
I needed a dial indicator holder that I could use on my CR-10 with the fang fan, and found https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2651655, but it was for a smaller diameter barrel than the one I had. I have the Harbor Freight analog dial indicator, and it has a 9.5mm barrel. I increased the barrel size to 10mm, and added a piece that you can put a 4mm diameter (m4?) bolt through to tighten it down on the indicator.

UPDATE: An M4 bolt is really tight in the clamp, but if you screw it all the way in and keep going, it will clear it out enough. Also, I would recommend supports, at least for the part that mounts to the roller. It was at just enough of an angle that mine wasn't super clean. Not to the point where I need to reprint it, just kind of rough towards the top.

title: PTFE to Prusa Multi Material Extruder filament guide

description.text:
This adapter snaps onto the extruder motor mount of Prusa i3 Mk2 MultiMaterial extruder.

This prevents a small radius bend and kinking of your filament;

With a short tube, you can do things like mount your filament above your printer, or with a long PTFE tube, you can load your filament more conveniently and "remotely" by loadining the filament from outside of your printer enclosure.

Two files are included, one for 4mm OD and the other for 5mm OD PTFE tube.

remixed_from.author: dirtsky
remixed_from.title: Ikea Enclosure for Monoprice Maker Select/Wanhao Duplicator i3

title: Wanhao Lack Triple Stack Enclosure Attack: With Sliding Control Box & Removable Top
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A collection of enhanced parts and mods to make the perfect Wanhao i3 / Maker Select / Cocoon Create enclosure.

This enclosure has the following features:

  • Removable Top: Easily lift and remove the top of the enclosure for easy access and maintenance of the printer. The legs are lifted 60mm to ensure there is plenty of room inside. Total internal volume is 510x510x450mm.
  • Deployable Control Box: The underslung control box can slide out when needed or slid back in to save space.
  • Filament Guide: Contains a chamber for sponge to clean filament as it feeds through. Also contains a PTFE guide to feed filament directly into the extruder. This prevents striations as the filament is fed through smoother.
  • Optimized for silence: Use of EVA foam, sorbothane, rubber feet and butyl flashing to reduce vibrations and decouple the printer.
  • ToolHolder: Neatly holds the essentials such as the 5 stock allen keys, scrapper, needle nose pliers, thickness gauge tool and a screwdriver.
  • Inset Hinge: Inset door and hinge set 20mm from the edge.
  • Triple Stack Lack

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20-40%

Notes:

Printed in PLA

This requires 2 to 3 Ikea lack tables. They are cheap and perfectly sized for creating a 3d printer enclosure. I shortened the legs of the bottom 2 lacks to reach my preferred height. I took 3cm from the bottom lack and 2cm from the middle lack. These parts will work either way.

Wanhao Lack - Tool Holder: Can be glued, taped or screwed to the side of a lack.

Wanhao Lack - Stacker X4: For stacking a lack on another lack.

Wanhao Lack - PTFE Filament Guide and Sponge Cleaner: Drill a 14mm hole in the top lack. Slide in the clip to secure the guide in place. Place some folded sponge into the hole on top, run some PTFE into the bottom. Designed around 3MM OD PTFE tube, if you are using 4mm PTFE you may need to drill it out a bit. Run the PTFE into the extruder with this https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:877258.

Wanhao Lack - Perspex Top Brackets X6: Screw into the top of the legs of the top lack. 20mm from the outside edge. Should be flush with the inside edge of the legs. Two for each leg. Front left, Back left and Back right.

Wanhao Lack - Lid Plug Bottom X3: Screw onto the top of the middle lack. Should be positioned back right, back left and Front left. The top table will mount on top of these.

Wanhao Lack - Lid plug - Door Hinge Right: Screw into the top of the middle lack as above. Position front right.

Wanhao Lack - Lid Lifter - Rear left & Right X2: Screw onto the bottom of the legs of the top lack. Back left and back right legs.

Wanhao Lack - Lid Lifter - Front Left - Handle Side: Screw onto the bottom of the leg of the top lack as above. Front left leg.

Wanhao Lack - Lid Lifter - Door Hinge Right: Screw onto the bottom of the leg of the top lack as above. Front right leg. The hinge mechanism screws into this.

Wanhao Lack - Hinge - Perspex Door Holder X2: Notch the top right and bottom right corners of the perspex door by 15mm high and 35mm long. Slide in the hinge holder and screw them in.

Wanhao Lack - Hinge Bracket Top Right: Screws into the top lack, top of the front right leg. The "Wanhao Lack - Hinge - Perspex Door Holder X2" part fits into this.

Wanhao Lack - Hinge Bracket Bottom Right: Screws into "Wanhao Lack - Lid plug - Door Hinge Right". Sandwich the door in place before screwing in place.

Wanhao Lack - Filament Holder Feet: Used this filament holder. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2003149. Screwing this directly into the lack transmits vibrations directly into the table and causes excess noise. Glue these to the bottom of the guide along with rubber stoppers to make it much quieter.

Wanhao Lack - Feet X4: When shortening the feet more than 20mm They hollow out. use these to provide a stable flat surface, attach felt stopper to reduce noise.

Wanhao Lack - Control Box Slider Bracket X2: Two of these on the bottom of the middle lack table. May need to trial and error placement to allow the control box to fully slide in and out. The Screws on the bottom of the box limit the distance that the box can slide. I placed mine rouchly 120mm in and 220mm in.

Wanhao Lack - Cable Guide: Cut a 30x45mm hole into the back of the middle lack. allows the Wanhao cable to route to the control box below.

Use layers of butyl flashing to mass load the lack tables. This reduces vibrations and annoying drumming.Place on the top of the middle lack. under the middle lack. And under the top lack.
https://www.bunnings.com.au/consolidated-alloys-75mm-x-3m-weatherproof-byute-flash-flashing-tape_p1100468

Add sorbothane legs to the bottom of the printer. Place a thick layer of EVA form on top of the middle table. This decouples the printer from the enclosure and significantly reduces noise.
https://www.bunnings.com.au/polytuf-50-x-50cm-solid-black-foam-mats-4-pack_p4490382

The Sides are 3mm Clear Acrylic Sheets Sized at 444mm x 449mm. Mount with 3M x 10 screws using soft washers such as these. https://www.bunnings.com.au/zenith-22mm-epdm-dome-washer-50-pack_p2409517

The door handle and magnets have metal accents in order to give a nice contrast with the black lack tables and 3d printed parts. The door magnets are sourced cheaply from ebay and the handles are available from any hardware store. https://www.bunnings.com.au/prestige-96mm-brushed-nickel-half-round-and-square-handle_p4020608

This is designed with a left handed door in mind. To have the handle on the right hand side mirror the following parts.

  • Wanhao Lack - Hinge Bracket Bottom Right.stl
  • Wanhao Lack - Hinge Bracket Top Right.stl
  • Wanhao Lack - Lid Lifter - Door Hinge Right.stl
  • Wanhao Lack - Lid Lifter - Front Left - Handle Side.stl
  • Wanhao Lack - Lid plug - Door Hinge Right.stl

comments.text: Should Lid plug - Door Hinge Right be mirrored too for a right hand side handle? And can't (Lid Lifter - Door Hinge Right.stl) and (Lid Lifter - Front Left - Handle Side.stl)  just be reversed instead of mirror. Anyway cool design. I am in the middle of printing this. Looks cool and will post pictures when I am done. Thanks!

comments.text: I'm in the process of printing the control box brackets now and I'm wondering how you positioned the brackets to both allow the control box to slide in and out, and still maintain access to the USB port.  I have my printer hooked up to a RPi with OctoPi installed, and I don't want to have it get unplugged every time I pull the control box out.
comments.author: jchaager

comments.text: For anyone wondering, I ended up positing the brackets with the rear edges 2" (~50mm) and 10 1/4" (~260mm) from the front edge of the table.  This allows the rear screws on the bottom of the control box to catch on the rear bracket when the box is extended, and the front screws to catch on the front bracket when it is retracted and prevents the cable from impacting the brackets in either position.
comments.author: jchaager

This was our final project for 3DX. It was our personal project :)
Here is a link to my project video: https://youtu.be/bsfV1Jvi9NU

I was inspired by Robert Robert's design (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pQwgZwrXfhc) but wanted to make a smaller version.

I got the acrylic blocks from Amazon: https://www.amazon.com/Krystal-Acrylic-Block-Set-5/dp/B002PI8ZCU

To pin A0, I attached the Adafruit Electret Microphone Amplifier - MAX9814 with Auto Gain Control [ADA1713] to "listen" to the sound level which tells the Arduino nano which pattern of lights to run.

I modified the code found here: http://textuploader.com/5bf3a
but changed line 12 to #define NUMBER_PIXEL 15 since I was using 15 neopixels running the same code but in opposite directions.

I soldered the neopixel data wires together and attached them to pin 6. The functions in the program are mapped on to different sound levels to give the music various light effects.

This is a remake of the Lulzbot© Taz 6©, their version is a 300x300x300 mm build, mine is a 300x300x560mm build, approx. 12x12x22 inches. This build is in the works still, but should be buildable with the parts I have uploaded. I would like to thank Anthony (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2056402) for his help over this build, and Tech2c (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1752766) for having a great list of parts for screws, bolts, etc that he is using for his 3d printer. I will be building his build next, only with a 300x300x450mm volume. I went overboard, and therefore my cost is going to be about $1000 usd, however, I’m sure the build can be done for much less if you shop around. I am using the Prometheus system (https://www.thingiverse.com/RPIronMan/designs) (https://www.distechautomation.com/products/prometheus-system)
I will supply anyone with step files or creo part files that messages me and requests them. I usually respond within a hour, less if I’m not busy.
Enjoy the build, and let me know if you decide to build it.

title: Graphtec CB09 Blade Holder Mount For Creality CR-10

description.text:
This holder is designed to mount directly to the stock fan housing of the Creality CR-10. This is designed to hold the Graphtec CB09 Blade Holder (I found it really cheap on eBay). The assembly is adjustable in the Z-axis. I would recommend making an adjustable mount for the limit switch of the z-axis; you will want to elivade the hotend away from the build plate (or simply tighten the buildplate down). The parts are not modeled very well, I was in a rush. I printed them out of ABS (I was out of everything else) on my Creality CR-10. It works great!

I used inkscape with martymcguire's inkscape-unicorn add-on fromGitHub to write the G-Code. I had a lot of issues with offset and units in inkscape; once I figured out offset and scaling, I made a .SVG template. I use CAMotics to test the G-Code before.

Some modification to the G-Code is needed. The inkscape-unicorn add-on is written such that the G-Code uses a servo to lift the a pen. Just change code where it says (pen up) and (pen down) to move z axis up or down.

I will be more than happy to make tutorial for anyone interested.

description.text:
Do you want the best Elite Dangerous / Flight Simulator Cockpit experience? Then these 3D printed Joystick mounts are what you need. Offering a swivel and removable design they sit in the most comfortable place for long hours of gameplay. Quickly swivel them out of the way for easy sit-down and stand-up. Easily detach from the chair when not in use.

Video of working swivel: https://youtu.be/-F06L80E2zE

The chair mounts have been specially designed for the Baku Medium Back Chair from Office Works.

Chair Link: https://www.officeworks.com.au/shop/officeworks/p/baku-medium-back-chair-white-jbbakumbwh

Printed everything in PLA on the Anycubic I3 Mega
The print time is around 3-4 days.

I wanted to have my Galaxy Nexus connected to my bike, just like my navigation-system is connected in my car. So I designed a simple holder that could be assembled only using a couple of cable binders. My Galaxy Nexus clips in perfectly tight. It is not too tight, so you can easyly remove it, but also it is tight enough so you wont loose it hitting bumps on the road. PLEASE READ: I am using a protection cover on my Nexus. This specific one: http://goo.gl/hwUIx.
So all the dimensions are taken with the protection cover on the phone. So just the phone without the cover wont fit! But I assume that most people are using a cover, or know how to adjust the parts, just shorten them by 1 mm or so.. Unfortunately I can't upload any fotos of it, because I am currently on vacation, and the bike I have connected it to is back home in germany.

Print all the parts out. You might need to adjust the diameter of the bike clip on the base part, depending on the diameter of the handelbar rod of your bike.
A1 and A2 need to be put together and connected to one side of the base using a cable binder. B1 and B2 are connected to the other side of the base, also using a cable binder. Then the complete assembly is connected to the bike using two additional cable binders.
I included a .blend file. There you can see all parts correctly assembled.

description.text:
Paint it after you print it to give it your own style or go with the original Nyan Cat colors!

It comes in pieces so smaller printers can still print it. Just glue them together or print it in ABS and acetone bond them.

With only the base and head the Nyan Cat pokes out just a bit with normal sized paper towels. You can print the extension bar (or as many as you want) for bonus rainbows or basketball player paper towels.

For an original Nyan Cat look:

  • red, yellow, blue, green, orange, and purple for the rainbow
  • light brown for the pop tart crust
  • light pink frosting and dark pink sprinkles for the strawberry pop tart flavor
  • dark gray for the Nyan cat head and feet

Designed while teaching myself Fusion 360. Hope it brings some smiles!

title: 3D printed articulating LED lamp - Phone holder

description.text:
I was looking for a solution to hold my phone in place while I watch videos while eating or before going to sleep. Holding the phone in the air can be tiring.

I designed it in multiple parts to make it easy to print without support. Some printers may struggle with the thigh tolerance. OpenSCAD files available on demand.

I did multiple iterations on the ball joint. When I print it bigger, it breaks during assembly / handling. At current scale, it require strength to assemble and careful handling for the first few movements. I designed the ball joint with 0 tolerance to hold the phone in place after handling, but it's not working well. After multiple uses, the ball joint become loose. I'm looking for alternative.

title: Nerf Barricade pusher support post replacement

description.text:
This replaces the central post of a Barricade/Stockade's trigger mechanism - the post on which the pusher slides and the lever rotates. This rod experiences a fair bit of force in normal use, especially when the trigger is pulled while the jam door lock is engaged, and sometimes breaks.

Printing in a horizontal orientation (as it is currently laid out) should provide the most strength.

This is a test version and some of the dimensions may be a bit off. Some may be more than a bit off.

author: cbarmstrong

description.text: This is just a silly little design I did, to help with my phone's finicky-ness about charge cords. Basically, I've only ever been able to find one charge cord that actually makes contact with the port in my phone enough to charge it. All other cords stop charging unless I hold them at a specific angle, and holding my phone to charge it got tedious real quick. So I hashed out a design that would fit over my phone, with a surface at the bottom to hold the charger in the correct position for me (then I did a pattern on the whole thing because patterns are cool, lol). It worked like a dream, so I thought I'd share the design on the off-chance anyone else has had similar problems with finicky phones. Keep in mind, you will most likely need to resize the file to fit over your phone or phone case. Open it in Meshmixer, and use the 'measure' tool under analysis, to measure the interior dimensions of the file. Then measure your phone. Use the 'transform' tool under edit, to tweak the width and depth of the file until the measurements match. Save, export, print.

author: Aurion55

print_settings.Notes:: Needs an XY offset compensation of at least -0.05 mm for pieces to fit if no infill is used. Some infills protrude the perimeter slightly so it may interfere with the clearance, if this happens, then use an XY compensation of -0.1 mm. You may also need to trim away the excess of your first layer. What worked for me was to use a single perimeter wall and a concentric 5% infill such that there are no infill corners on the sides of the piece. You can use no infill and two perimeter walls if you wish but it will take longer to print. The file with the largest number of pieces should print in a little over 2 hours with the smaller one taking only 1 hour with a layer resolution of 0.3 mm. The Test file should print in only 30 minutes.

description.text: Remix of hudson fractal puzzle for 3d printers. Print it in one or many colours, I particularly like the black & white set shown here. I modified the puzzle to be a 31 piece puzzle to make it slightly harder. It is a hard puzzle to build as it is. I included a Test stl file so you can print a known pair of interlocking pieces and test for clearances before you set out to print the complete puzzle. Pieces have been design with no clearances so you will need to give it an XY offset compensation of at least -0.05 mm for them to fit. Enjoy!!

comments.text: How exactly do you go about adding that "XY offset"? I would love to print this but I'm not sure how to do this. Do you have versions of the files with the clearance already added? Thanks.
comments.author: mas0n

comments.text: Hi Mas0n, you will find the “XY size compensation” setting in the “advanced” section of the slic3r settings or the “horizontal size expansion” in cura. Make sure your “expansion” shrinks the piece (negative expansion). It is a slicer setting that is why there is no offseted stl file. Use the Test.stl file provided that has a pair of known interlocking pieces until you find a setting that makes the assembly easy. The actual value will depend on your machine calibration and the first layer settings but the only way to find it is by trial and error.
comments.author: mas0n

title: Daily Wear Contacts Dispenser Rack - Acuvue Oasys

description.text:
Instead of keeping the Left and Right contact lenses in the boxes so they don't get confused during the week, I wanted to put them in a dispenser rack. This is designed to mount with Command Strips.

This was designed specifically for Acuvue Oasys daily contact lenses. The curve at the end was designed so they don't slip out, but there's enough friction it's not really needed, and requires a bit more force to slip past than I would have originally liked. It's not a problem, as the open face allows you to slide the contact lens strip through. Alternatively, I made (but haven't printed) a version without the curve.

title: McCormick Spice Cap Inserts (Small Holes and Scraper)

description.text:
So, apparently McCormick used to include scrapers in some of their caps as well as smaller holes for spices that you don't want to dump half the bottle. Over time, they have slowly converted their caps to, what I can only assume, more standardized caps across all of their spices. (Information sourced from my significant other.)
Included are a scraper for leveling your measuring spoons and a 9x1mm hole cap for those spices that need smaller holes.
Please note the following:

  1. The holes are drawn at 2mm, but since smaller holes tend to not be the proper size, these come out to 1mm on my printer. Yours may differ.
  2. These are press fit with a lip that goes inside the container and fit under the original cap. Any slight variance in printer calibration may prevent these from fitting properly.
  3. I recommend printing directly to glass to give a smooth top surface for the final part. Also, be careful with your first layer squish as it could close off the holes if it is squished too much.
  4. I do not advise using 3D printed parts for any food contact surfaces. Use at your own risk!

Printer:

ANET A8

Notes:

Print directly to glass for smooth top finish.
Be sure your printer is calibrated properly or these will not fit.

title: Wanhao i3 Ramps, Rasp Pi, and Mosfet Control Box Combo Adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
An adapter for the Wanhao I3 control box to upgrad the original Melzi electronics. This allows a Ramps1.4, a Raspberry Pi 2/3, and a mosfet to fit snugly into the existing control box.

I used this Mosfet
It is more than capable of handling the heatbed current. Any moset with a spacing of 38mm x 63mm will fit without issues.

The Adaptor fits on top of the existing mounting holes and is secured with M3 screws and washers. Everything can be mounted with M3 screws.

I also recommend switching out the rear fan with an 120mm adaptor to keep everything cool.

If you use a RepRapDiscount Full Graphic Smart Controller such as the one in this ramps kit, it is a drop in replacement for the old Melzi LCD. The SD card is built into the screen so you will loose the ability to switch out SD cards, however this is not really an issue if you also are also moving to Octopi.

I also recommend this Ramps guide

title: Roost Laptop stand modifcation to fit thicker laptops (endorsed By Roost Industries Corp.)

description.text:
The Roost laptop stand is great, but it does not accomodate for thicker laptops. A laptop with a bottom edge thicker than 0.75" (1.9 cm) will either not fit in the Roost, or it will seem like it will fit, but then be prone to sliding out, and falling out of the stand.

The design changes the laptop holder plastic bits, one per side, that clamp the laptop.

It's a simple quick print, and then the pieces can be replaced to the originals.

This modification has full permission from Roost Industries Corp. for use in open source community.

title: How to get a good start when using a Z nozzle probe.

description.text:
Even with a well made machine not requiring auto bed level, from time to time, you have to adjust the Z end stop. For ex. when you change the extruder, remove the glass plate etc...

So I got rid of the Z regular home switch and made one triggered by the nozzle contacting the bed to do the job. Forget about bulky, heavy, clumsy solutions like proximity sensors, BLTouch, ridiculous microswith mounted on a servo ...They all need adjustment anyway, therefore defeating the purpose and often are unreliable.

To use the nozzle as a probe, various ready solutions exist: piezo, strain gauge, vibration sensor, mechanical switch ...Do your search and pick the one you want that can be best integrated in your hot end/carriage or design your own :)

Caveat: The nozzle must be clean and the bed place it will hit must be free from hole, filament blobs ...
I don't like the idea of scraping the nozzle, it can easily be damaged. PETG is pretty sticky, so good luck.
When the bed is covered with a sheet of BuildTack or similar, the home position is usually a hole after the blobs of melted plastic have been scraped or damaged by the hot nozzle.

Yet, the solution is simple. Just a small piece of PTFE self adhesive sheet at the home position and a simple procedure that can be done manually of via a G code script to be run at print start.

Bring the nozzle up to T° and home. Make sure the nozzle stays at home. You can home a second time to make sure the melted filament is expelled. Note, my sensor needs about 1N. If adjusted too light, you may have issues.

Eventually, when the job is done, remove the print and home while the nozzle is still hot. The nozzle resting at home will prevent oozing and you will start clean the next print.

The PTFE sheet will protect the BuildTack and any blob will be easy to remove. Could even be reinforced by a thin smaller metal sheet (0.1) underneath

With a 0.1 mm sheet you will get the right distance to bed. Adjust the Z offset eventually, especially if you use a thicker sheet (which in fact will be stronger and last longer).
If required cut a portion of the BuildTack leaving just the strong adhesive and stick the PTFE piece.

As you can see, the nozzle face is flush despite no preliminary cleaning had been done and there was melted PETG sticking to it.
Time I install a silicone shroud :

PS: The stl is there just because Thingiverse requires one.

comments.text: Are you levelling when things are heated, ready to go, or when they're all cold? There's a huge difference between the two. A clean nozzle is a must but when it's been heated, there could be "constant" oozing to keep clean. Also, sort of stupid to be tapping the bed with a hot nozzle if it can cause dabs on the print bed - depends on the bed material of course. What's the sensitivity of this contraption? How does it compare to the Precision Piezo?
comments.author: jmtx

comments.text:
It must be hot, in fact at working T° so what is oozing, left over will be crushed and will not introduce errors.
This is why you need a PTFE small piece because Buildtak or similar will be damaged. Easy to clean too.
PTFE sheet can be found in store or in laser printers drum.

description.text:
This is a tablet stand for use at my work. I am designing it so it's ultra flexible in the angle you want to use. They were designed to use apoxy in the connections, but the friction fit seemed to be quite snug.
Required materials
200g ABS+ preferably
1x Suction cup mount -https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B013QRGX36/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

1x 1/4" washer
1x 1/4" nut (I'm not using a nylon locking nut because in order to adjust the sliding you need to unscrew the nut with the actual printed part)

Printer:

Duplicator I3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.12

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I use a 1.6 wall thickness with a .4mm head
A universal spool holder to work with all spools and 8mm rod. Insert a 608Z bearing and you're good to go. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/hHUOU2XAy4L

author: deffi3211

title: SwivelHips Kit for the HiTecRCD RoboNova-1 BiPedal Robot

description.text:
This is a MakerBotable kit to modify a RoboNova-1 and add another DOF so the legs can pronate and supanate while keeping the height of the RoboNova-1 very nearly the same as the original 30cm height ... and this allows for the c.g. to remain lower for more stability. I upgraded the servo drive horn with splines on the inside bore ... albiet I don't have a caliper that small ... I'll can only eye-ball and guess. This kit will make your RoboNova-1 slightly wider and thicker, but even side-by-side they appear very much the same size. And as usual, every part here is designed to be MakerBotable with a CupCake MakerBot ... except for the rubber band ... get one from your local post office! I wish I had a MakerBot to actually build and test my creations! See a video demonstrating the added value and size comparisons.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WgHBmt8g67w
or see the animated .GIF
http://www.brainless.org/MultiMedia/Pictures/SW-Portfolio/MultiMedia/SwivelHipsNova-1+RoboNova-1.gif I plan on uploading the aluminum bracket SolidWorks .SLDPRT files to the 3D Content Central Library soon ...
http://www.3dcontentcentral.com/Search.aspx?arg=wperko This is another of many entries to the makezine.com/go/makerbot contest ... blog.makezine.com/archive/2010/04/makerbot_giveaway.html

MakerBot the pieces ... one of each except for the Front/Back parts where you make two of each ... 
Make me a couple of sets if you can ... I wanna upgrade my RoboNova-1 too!
If you successfully make this with a 3D printer please send me the build-file and machine type so it can be uploaded here for others to use.

comments.author: jmakarew

author: SolidWorksMagi

description.text:
These are parameterized connectors for building small domes for learning. They are based on effalo's V2 dome kit. I have re-written the scad files so that now it is possible to make small connectors that work with wooden sticks of very small diameter (3mm or less). I have tested it building 2 domes that I've called as Mini-dome and Micro-dome, with diameters of 50cm and 15cm respectivelly. I have used wooden sticks with section of 3 and 2 mm, that are very cheap and very easy to find. The connectors are parameterized. The user has to introduce the stick diameter (in mm) and the holedepth. The size of the connector (radius and height) will be automatically calculated. (More information in Spanish)
La versiÃ³n en EspaÃ±ol la puedes ver aquÃ­:
http://www.iearobotics.com/wiki/index.php?title=Objeto_3D:_Mini_domo

You can calculate your own stick length according to the total dome's diameter requiered: http://simplydifferently.org/Geodesic_Dome_Notes?page=3#2V/L2 I have precalculated 2 examples. Example 1: Micro-dome
  • Diameter: 150 mm
  • Height: 75mm
  • 20 x Hexa-connectors
  • 6 x Penta-connectors
  • 35 x Long sticks: 46.3mm (Green)
  • 30 x shot sticks: 41mm (Red)
    • Example 2: Mini-dome
  • Diameter: 50cm
  • Height: 25cm
  • 20 x Hexa-connectors
  • 6 x Penta-connectors
  • 35 x Long sticks: 154.5 mm (Green)
  • 30 x shot sticks: 136.6 mm (Red)

title: Power Supply Mounting Brackets
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These are "Mean Well" type power supply mounting brackets. You will be able to mount this type of power supply on a surface using screws. This bracket is quite sturdy.

The slot in the bracket that holds the power supply supports up to M4 screws. It is recommended that you use washers. The hole used to screw the power supply to the surface are 5 mm in diameter.

author: ctheroux

description.text: 3-D printable physical pixel creature logo for MULTI-MANIA -- a creative, interactive, emerging technology conference held in Kortrijk, Belgium. "Multi-Mania 2014: Get inspired, share knowledge and connect with the creative community! The Multi-Mania conference has become the annual event that brings together designers, developers, entrepreneurs and creative new media students. The enthusiasm surrounding this event is exciting and inspiring. Each year the conference grows a little bigger and each year the experience gets a little better. As the new media industry grows, the importance of a conference like Multi-Mania increases. Attendees learn from industry leaders, catch up on the latest developments and find new energy and inspiration for their work. New business relationships are built, new products are developed, innovative solutions are found, and employees and students come into contact with employers and schools. At this 14th edition of Multi-Mania, we expect to welcome over 2000 multimedia developers, designers, entrepreneurs, multimedia students and lecturers." For more information, please refer to: http://www.multi-mania.be/
Traced outline in inkscape to .dxf, and imported into SolidWorks, then cleaned it up, exported to .STL for 3-D Printing.

author: aspen88

print_settings.Notes:: Print with thick walls for max. strength. I'm used 2mm thick walls

description.text:
This is rev.1 of my 3D printed drone racing frame. Suitable for 5inch propellers and 3S/4S LiPo has a place for "standard" FPV camera and 36x36mm flight controller and PDB (30.5mm hole spacing).

Youtube video

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Print with thick walls for max. strength. I'm used 2mm thick walls

To assemble you will need:

8x M3x45mm bolts
4x M3x12 bolts
12x M3 nuts
A lot of M3 washers. I suggest a washer for each nut and bolt

Depending on the thickness of your flight controller stack, you will need 4 additional M3 nuts and bolts. You can either just attach your stack with M3x20 or something like that, but for better frame stiffness I suggest printing some standoffs and attaching everything with 4 additional M3x45 nuts through the top plate.

description.text:
Coffee capsule holder for 43mm capsules on average
at other capsule size easy

yourcapsulemm / 43mm = ABSOLUTE

Example: 30mm / 43mm = 0.698
That means in your 3D program Cura or any scale to 70%.
my walls have 2% tolerance and always round up.

Have fun drinking coffee

Beispiel: 30mm/43mm=0,698
Das heißt in deinem 3D Programm Cura oder beliebig auf 70% skalieren.
meine Wände lassen 2% Toleranz und immer aufrunden.

Viel Spaß beim Kaffee trinken

description.text: Wrist pad extension for Corsair K95 keyboard. Now this is the only perfect keyboard on the market.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

10

Notes:

I printed it standing.

The motivation

I was looking for a perfect keyboard. There are tons of keyboards on the market but every one has some disadvantage. My requirements were:

  • fully RGB
  • comfort and good quality mechanical swithes (finally I choosed MX Cherry Brown)
  • music control buttons
  • good (high and wide) wrist pad (you know how big height of the mechanical swithes is)
  • some extra keys if possible (not must-to-have but only nice-to-have)
    I bought 5 of the best keyboards and tried them. No one was perfect. I finally kept the K95 because the only problem was the wrist pad and it was easy extendable. Now with my extension, it is perfect :) I hope you will enjoy it same as me.

author: oleeskildsen

title: Curvy Lampshade E27 one layer thick

description.text:
Lampshade designed with a 0.4mm layer thickness for a print with a thickness of 1 layer filament. Print with a high fan speed. I used a (Innofil3d premium filament) creamy white PLA and 75% fan speed. You can use a normal lamp fitting with E27 40mm outer thread. This was about the maximum size my printer can print, and the print takes about 5 hours on my printer.

Only use LED lamps within this shade to prevent it from melting!

title: 96 well plate / 8 tube strip magnetic separator

description.text:
96 well magnetic plate holder for isolating magnetic beads in a 96 well plate or for individual pcr tubes on the side racks. After printing, 16 block magnets (K & J magnetics cat. no. BX022) will need to be attached to the plastic (I used a craft glue called E6000, which should be used with a respirator or in the fume hood).

ORIENTATION OF THE MAGNETS IS IMPORTANT. You want the North-South line to be going from one set of the the 8-well tube holders to the other; so that the North-South line is parallel to the floor/table.

Printer:

Wanhao i3 duplicator v2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

60%

Designing / Editing

I used blender for all of the designing and exported to a .stl file.

title: Add laser ON OFF custom menu in Marlin 1.6.6 for M42 P___ pin 44

description.text:
How to add laser turn ON turn OFF command for Marlin microcode with gcode M42 P44 pin
Marlin verision 1.1.6
change configuration_adv.h in section

define CUSTOM_USER_MENUS

if ENABLED(CUSTOM_USER_MENUS)

define USER_SCRIPT_DONE "M117 User Script Done"

// #define USER_SCRIPT_AUDIBLE_FEEDBACK
// #define USER_SCRIPT_RETURN // Return to status screen after a script

define USER_DESC_1 "Turn Laser Off"

define USER_GCODE_1 "M42 P44 S0"

define USER_DESC_2 "Turn Laser On"

define USER_GCODE_2 "M42 P44 S255"

define USER_DESC_3 "G1 X180 Y180 Z45" //used for laser height calibration

define USER_GCODE_3 "G1 X180.0 Y180.0 Z45.0"

define USER_DESC_4 "G1 X0 Y0 Z0" //used for laser height calibration

define USER_GCODE_4 "G1 X0.0 Y0.0 Z0.0"

define USER_DESC_5 "G1 X0 Y0" //used for laser height calibration

define USER_GCODE_5 "G1 X0 Y0"

endif

description.text: A more reliable spool holder arm which can be screwed to the frame. You need an M4 T-slot and an M4x12 or M4x15 bolt.

Hello everybody
I thought it would not be bad if a driver figure were sitting in the ossum jeep. there are ready to buy driver's dolls, but are relatively expensive, so I've looked at thingiverse, if there are not appropriate templates for printing and I've found it. At thingiverse.com/thing:2508858 I found exactly what I was looking for. My thanks here directly to SAGEA, who published this figure in August 2017. I combined this figure together with the seat of the Ossum Jeep and put it together as an STL file. The result can be seen here.
I then painted my figure with acrylics, gray was not so popular. In order to mount the figure seated, the steering wheel must be disassembled and flexibly attached in the connection, I have taken a piece of 3mm filament, because then can be deformed and the mounting on the seat is possible.

hallo zusammen
ich habe mir gedacht, es wäre nicht schlecht, wenn im ossum jeep auch eine fahrerfigur sitzen würde. es gibt fertige fahrerpuppen zu kaufen, sind aber relativ teuer, deshalb habe ich mich bei thingiverse umgesehen, ob es nicht entsprechende Vorlagen zum drucken gibt und bin dabei fündig geworden. Bei thingiverse.com/thing:2508858 habe ich genau das gefunden, was ich gesucht habe. Meinen Dank hier direkt an SAGEA, der diese Figur im August 2017 veröffentlichte. Ich habe diese Figur zusammen mit dem Sitz vom Ossum Jeep kombiniert und als STL-File zusammen gestellt. Das Ergebnis seht ihr hier.
Meine Figur habe ich dann noch mit Acrylfarben angemalt, grau war nicht so der Renner. Um die Figur mit Sitz montieren zu können, muss das Lenkrad demontiert werden und flexibel im Anschluss angebracht werden, ich habe dazu ein Stück 3mm Filament genommen, weil sich das dann verformen läßt und die Montage nach dem Sitz möglich ist.

title: Modular gaming hills
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Updated 2017-12-15: Added magnet holes like for the entrances

This is a set of pieces that lets you make hills for wargaming and roleplaying games. The pieces can be snap fitted together with the applied clip. There are different sizes so check out the possible combinations. Not everything fits with everything visually.

You can make full round hills, or edge hills (from two pieces) or corner hills (from one piece).

You should be able to print with very low infill. I use 5% honeycomb.

The hills on the pictures have been painted with different techniques. The desert hill is painted dark muddy brown the drybrushed with a lighter color. They dark grassy hill is painted black and then drybrushed with lighter and lighter grays. The lighter hills are painted white and then washed with yellow, red, brown and black.

The hills are textured and flocked with a simple technique. Thin down PVA glue with 50% water. Paint on. Sprinkle sand and grit on them. Let dry. Spray or paint with PVA glue 80% water. Let dry again.

Support me on Patreon

This thing is delivered with the outstanding help from my patrons. To help me deliver quality printable terrain models, please pledge $1 or more:

Video presentation

https://youtu.be/xymxgjQhmSI

Miniatures used

Sci-fi miniatures used comes from pig-iron miniatures.
http://www.pig-iron-productions.com/

comments.text: If you switched to use the OpenLock clip, they even have a magnetic clip that they released a couple weeks ago.  Would give you a more standard clip design, and it would leave the magnet option for people who want it.  I have no idea how the "OpenLock" license works, but it seems to be a free process.  If you don't want to go that route, something as simple as two sets of two holes above/below the clip space could make it very easy to use a barrel magnet.  Just size it for some size of magnet that seems widely available.  I like to look at a big hardware store like Home Depot, do a search for "in-stock" magnets, and use one of those.  I figure if a big box store like HD has it in stock, it must be popular enough and available enough for people.

remixed_from.title: Turnigy Fabrikator Bed Levelling mount for Digital Tyre Gauge

description.text:
Used to mount one of these http://www.banggood.com/Digital-Tyre-Depth-Gauge-Tyre-Tread-Depth-Gauge-Measuring-Tool-p-953762.html on the rails to check the level of each corner.

Zero it by pushing it against the bed before mounting. It's best to sand down the end so it's nice and rounded to stop it scoring the tape you put on the bed.

I'm sure you can work out the rest....

Tip: only use a feather like touch to push the ruler down or it will push the bed down and you'll get a false reading.

This is a modified version of Turnigy Fabrikator Bed Levelling mount for Digital Tyre Gauge by cgcrute . http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:918738. He gets all the credit for the design. However the hooks on the back have been modified to fit the A8 style X-Axis.

This is my first attempt at a custom item, I hope you enjoy.

PROS:

  • You'll have to be VERY quiet!
    Â Â If an eye opens - pray.

  • You'd better keep your hands off already assembled

description.text:
This is a case with cover to hold up to ten 1S 3.7V Lipos (incl. Velcro) as used on the Eachine QX95 micro FPV quad or similar micros. The bottom of the box is split so you can print one green and the other red, powerchord on the red side means empty, green it's charged.

The thing consists of two models which I'd recommend to print seperately to get a consistent color, the "box" and the "top". For each there is a "SINGLE" file - use this if you don't have a multicolor printer and want to print all in one color. The bottom won't be split then and you'll have to mark the sides with something (marker, paint, sticker) yourself.

If you have a Prusa MMU you can make good use of all 4 colors, print the inside green and red and the outside with different colors. Use all files which are NOT labeled "SINGLE" to print the multicolored versions. Also check the print settings I've used to mix colors like signal yellow and black and to have the top cover fit on the box neatly with just a slight resistence.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2 MMU

Rafts:

0.15

100% rectangular

Prusa3D Slic3r MK2 Multi Material Settings:

  • 1st Layer: 0.2, all other 0.15
  • Vertical Shells: 1
  • Top/Bottom Layers 3
  • Quality: all (the box in the pic was without "Avoid crossing Perimeters" and had minor stringing between the spacers)
  • Seam Position: rear
  • Wipe Tower: per color change: 25mm
  • Interface Shells: true

Note: the top will be printed on the surface, place the model on the cleanest part of your bed ;)

title: JG Aurora A5 Feet and Washers
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These are parts I've used to do two things...

  1. Enable me to fit little 6mm spacers to the feet to lift the machine up a bit. Mine was rocking on the centre section. I'm not sure if it's just my machine but adding these solved it. I used M4x16mm screws. The chamfer goes to the top.

  2. Added these little plastic washers to stop the side plastic bits rattling. You might / might not need these.

The A5 is a great printer, very happy with mine :-)

Da ich es zu schade finde, wenn die LP's mit ihren schönen Covern nebeneinander im Regal verschwinden hatte ich die Idee ein paar davon an die Wand (Tür) zu bringen.
Dazu habe ich mir diese Halterungen Entworfen.
ausgelegt sind die Ecken für max 9mm dicke Cover (Das Dickste was in meiner Sammlung vorhanden ist) wenn dünnere Platten eingelegt werden sollen lege ich kleine Rechteckige Schaumstoffzuschnitte mit 20x20x5mm in die Ecken damit nichts klappern kann.

Zum ankleben verwende ich Doppelseitiges Montageklebeband von 3M und Rauhe vorher die Rückseite der Druckteile mit grobem Schleifpapier an, danach werden die Klebeflächen (Druckteil und Tür) mit Isopropylalkohol entfettet. Das hält Bomben Fest.

DJI Spark Mavic Phone / Phablet Mount

6" Phone / Phablet mount for Spark / Mavic remote controller. It was designed for the Spark but should fit on the Mavic RC as well.

  • No screws needed
  • No extra parts needed
  • Easy to attach (snap-on)
  • The bracket spacing is 86.5mm

This mount was designed for the Cubot Max 6.0 phablet (with silikon protection case attached) but can also be used for any other phone of the same size (85mm - 86.5mm).

It comes in two versions: normal and extended. The extended version allows for some spacing between the phone and the RC. The normal version is a bit more compact.

An additional sun hood is included as well that can be attached on top of the phone. It fits thightly on the Cubot Max (with its silikone protection case).

Use a raft for good heatbed adhesion and 20% infill for best stability.

  • UPDATE:
    I uploaded an updated, tiltable version of this mount here:

print_settings.Notes:: Build plate adhession is a problem, therefore I have created a variant with a "support-ring", that connects the legs. Using this support-ring and a Brim should avoid adhession problems

description.text:
This year we had no "real" advent wreath, therefore our 3D-printer had to build one.

The part is created in FreeCAD, only the small sleigh at the top is another thingiverse-object: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1928834

I have uploaded 4 versions of STL-files: with and without sleigh, with and without support ring.

Build bed adhession is a problem with the original design. The support-ring should avoid this adhession problem. I would suggest to print the version with support ring and with a brim.

The advent wreath has a diameter of 256 mm, but you can scale it (eg. in Cura) to any size you like.

Leider haben wir etwas spät bemerkt, dass wir keinen echten Adventskranz besorgt hatten. Daher musste der 3D-Drucker für Abhilfe sorgen und das ist das Ergebnis.

Gezeichnet ist der Kerzenhalter in FreeCAD, nur der kleine Schlitten ist ein anderes Thingiverse-Objekt: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1928834

Als STL-Dateien habe ich mehrere Varianten hochgeladen:
Um Haftungsprobleme zu vermeiden habe, ich die Beine mit einem Ring verbunden (...with_support_ring...) .
Dazu gibt es jeweils eine Variante mit Schlitten (...with_sleigh...) und eine ohne.

Der Kerzenhalter hat einen Durchmesser von 256mm, dieser kann aber vor dem Druck (z.B. in Cura) beliebig verkleinert oder vergrößert werden.

description.text:
The Y stepper motor mount of the Tevo Tornado is a little bit wobbly. It will be worse, if you mount a noise damper between bracket and stepper.
This stabilizer supports the stepper motor at the baclk side an need only a little space.

  • Print with 50% infill.
  • Glue rubber or foam rubber on the surface towars the stepper back side to prevent transmitting the noise to the frame.
  • You need 2 4mm x 10mm screws with T-nuts for mountig the stabilizer on the frame.
You can keep the filament clean and give lubricant to the filaments.

This is a water-cooled alternative to the fan cooler on the RepRapPro Huxley and Mendel: http://reprappro.com

The device is a drilled and tapped brass block.  When it's been machined, blank the small hole ends by soldering in a few mm of brazing rod, and solder in a couple of 4mm copper tubes.  Connect it up with soft 3mm i.d. silicone tube to a small gear pump or similar.  The flow rate needed to keep it cool is not great.

comments.text: Have you experienced an increase in maximum print speed?
comments.author: Jumpmobile

comments.text: I haven't tried running things faster, but the water-cooled hot-end should reduce the friction between the filament and the nozzle where the filament enters the melt zone, so I would expect that your prediction is correct.
comments.author: Jumpmobile

comments.text: Have you considdered making a tiny peristaltic pump for that silicone tube? I have a minuscule one cooling the brush motor on one of my iRobot Roomba floor vac robots. It is an enclosed system with water jacket on the motor, and radiator in the brush airflow
comments.author: silverbrewer

comments.text: Yes - that would work well, and it's quite easy to print a peristaltic pump.  But you can get greater flow with a gear pump, and it's also easy to print that - especially as it doesn't have to be watertight (you just run it under water in the sump with the motor on a long shaft above).
comments.author: silverbrewer

comments.text: Have you considered making a tiny peristaltic pump for the silicone tube? I made a minuscule one to watercolour the brush motor on my Roomb

comments.text: Have you thought to replace the pump with a small peristaltic pump? The silicone tube lends itself to this pump type and I have successfully made an enclosed system to watercolour the brush motor on one of my iRobot Roomba floor cleaning robots
comments.author: silverbrewer

comments.text: I was wondering when ideas from computer overclocking would trickle into 3D printing!
comments.author: OoiTY

comments.text: This is something I would definitely go for once seeing convincing evidence that it results in significant improvements in either print quality or speed.
comments.author: gschwartz9

comments.text: Where do you have the fan's air flow directed, and how well focused (concentrated) on that location?
comments.author: gschwartz9

comments.author: gschwartz9

comments.text: Not at the moment - but I can say it works at least as well as the fan cooled version (which works very well).
comments.author: gschwartz9

comments.text: i have  build a test setup and now i have to find the sweet spot fore the Teflon to end near the hot end.
comments.author: michel-pet

comments.text: great id.
comments.author: michel-pet

comments.text: I haven't neasured the inflow and outflow temperatures with a thermometer, only with my finger :-)  I'll try and be a bit more scientific and post the results here asap.  The brass has a PTFE pad between it and the PLA frame.  But it (the brass) is only around 35 C in operation, so that's probably not needed (it's a good safety feature if the water fails, though).
comments.author: michel-pet

comments.text: I don't understand why we extract heat from a device that we are deliberately heating.
comments.author: gschwartz9

comments.text: The idea is to keep the melt zone as short as possible near the tip.  This has the advantage of minimising ooze, and minimising friction (both coulomb and viscous) as the filament is driven into the nozzle.  In particular, you don't have to retract the filament very far to stop the flow altogether.
comments.author: gschwartz9

comments.text: The point here is that in order for an extruder to run smoothly, the heat needs to be concentrated in a smallish zone, close to the nozzle.  If the plastic softens too high in the hot end, pressure from the extruder causes it to expand, and jams the hot end.  This mechanism cools the upper half of the hot end - not the print.
comments.author: gschwartz9

comments.text: Nice! What's on the other end? Tank, radiator, drain?

title: Knob for Vacuum Cleaner Kärcher WD 5

description.text:
L'aspirateur du lab ne fonctionnait plus.
Heureusement cela ne tenait qu'au bouton de mise en marche, fendu à l'intérieur par l'effort de rotation sur la tige en métal de l'actionneur (en forme de D : diamètre 6mm et méplat de 1,5mm sur 13mm de long).

Remplacer cette pièce non-critique fut une réparation facile, il y a seulement 5 vis type torx T15 pour plastique à démonter pour déloger le bouton en plastique.

Le nouveau bouton est monté légèrement contraint sur la tige en métal, ce qui permet de le monter après avoir remonté le capotage en plastique, ou bien un jour de le remplacer si besoin sans avoir à tout démonter.

Un aspirateur sauvé et 150€ économisés.

To make the soap

For mine I used candle wax, but I'm pretty sure soap could work as well.
First you need to clean a bit your, print and check for any holes in your mold. If there some , fill them up (varnish works well). Then put a fine layer of lacquer. The to help the released, put some dish soap one the mold. After that you can start pouring the wax or the soap(don't put to much). Wait until it's solid and put it in the freezer, and after that you can release your soap;
I used meshmixer and the fight soap by jodroboxes

title: Soporte simple para tira de leds bajo mueble de cocina

description.text:
Necesitaba iluminación bajo los muebles de cocina, pero no quería hacerles ninguna modificación o taladro, así que diseñe e imprimí este soporte, que casi no se puede ver en las imagenes que acompaño, ya que simplemente encajan detras de los muebles (hay que separarlos un poco con alguna herramienta como una espátula para encajarlos)...
Para fijarlos de forma mas segura, les añadí un poco de cinta adhesiva de doble cara, en la zona que quedaría "mordida" por el mueble y se han fijado extraordinariamente fuerte.
Para darle un poco de estética, lleva un perfil de aluminio de 25x25mm encajado justo encima de los soportes, lo que oculta los soportes y las catenarias que se forman debido a la flexibilidad de la propia tira de led, en total 2 metros de perfil, y 2 metros de LEDs.
Acompaño en diseño en FREECAD, por si fuese necesario adaptarlo a las dimensiones de otro modelo de tira de LED's, que hay muchas en el mercado.

Google translator to English...
I needed lighting under the kitchen furniture, but we did not want to use any modification or drill, so we designed and printed this support, which can hardly be seen in the images that accompany it, that simply fit the furniture little more than a tool like a spatula to fit them) ...
To fix them more securely, add a bit of double-sided adhesive tape, in the area that was "bite" for the furniture and fixed extraordinarily strong.
To give it a bit of aesthetics, it has a 25x25mm aluminum profile fitted over the supports, which hides the supports and catenaries that are formed due to the flexibility of the LED strip itself, a total of 2 meters in profile, and 2 meters of LED.
Accompanying design in FREECAD, if necessary, we must adapt it to the dimensions of another LED strip model, which there are many in the market.

description.text:
English below
Cet accouplement rigide permet de coupler l'axe d'un stepper avec une vis ISO de M2 a M14. tout est paramétrable avec Scad.Des écrous sont noyés dans la piece afin d'assurer le serrage. Merci a gaellafond pour sa librairie sur les helices qui m'a permis de parametrer les pas de vis.
This rigid coupling allows to connect the shaft of a stepper with a ISO screw from M2 to M14. Everything's customizable. Nuts are drowned in the workpiece to ensure tightening. Thanks to gaellafond for her library on helixe which allowed me to parametrize all the screws.

A collection of wall pieces inspired by look-alikes raider camp walls in the Fallout 3 gaming world.

Depending on slicer programme you use, the percent of infill and nozzle size you work with best, some features such as loose-attached barbwire and wood fixing may break off after print. This was done intentionally to create a level of personalization and also to allow a degree of customization for additional tecturing techniques such as flocking, wiring and congrugating cardboard to mask some of the layer-line imprefections that come with printing in FLM.

The full set of corner pieces can be purchased on Pinshape @ https://pinshape.com/items/41949-3d-printed-battlefield-scrap-and-concrete-wall-corners

The full set of straight pieces can be purchased on Pinshape @ https://pinshape.com/items/41951-3d-printed-battlefield-scrap-and-concrete-straight-walls

This is for the Franklin outdoor sports kit which includes 2 telescoping poles for holding the badminton net.
I bought this set at a yard sale. Primarily because my wife keeps winning at bowling and I'm looking for some way to restore my self respect so I figure .... badminton ... surely I can beat her at badminton. Granted, I am a right-hander bowling left-handed with one eye closed using a ball designed to fit the fingers of a very small 4 year old ... but still, she wins at bowling and I can't let it go at that.
well, short story long, it was a complete set in very good condition for only $3 ... sorry, wrong story ... so I get the kit home and discover the retaining pins for the telescoping poles were broken, all except for one. I uploaded a pic of a good pin with a broken pin so you can see exactly what I'm replacing. 
Recognizing that she is able to beat me at bowling and can probably do the same on the badminton court since I have to play left-handed on the side of the yard where the dog does his business, I demonstrate my 3D printing prowess and commence to design/print replacements for the broken pins.
Field tested, mother approved, these pins work great and will help provide you with hours of family fun in the backyard (or weeks of humilating defeat in my case).
Now, if I can just get the Olympic committee to add 3d printing as an officially recognized sport, I will finally be able to beat her at something.

this will probably make sense if you have poles such as the ones I bought with retaining clips that have broken.
slice, print and use

title: Tabletop Scenery - Junkyard Car Wreck Walls

description.text:
A collection of wrecked junkyard vehicles - stacked to create playable scenery walls and fort obstacles. These designs were compressed from architectural car drawings made in SketchUp 2004 and converted to .stl format.

I encourage you not to use supports for any of these print-outs. Lower-end printer users should be aware these are not incredibly dense models as I have built them on a rectangle filler that was stitched to simply print-proof the originally hollow car doors. This was done intentionally (and not lazy converting) to allow easier removal of cracks and splits in the model to create the appearance of rust and damage.

Adding supports may destroy the lower details of some of these designs leaving you with a flat rectangular base (most notably wreck-stacked_tall3 and wrecked_single1 I had initial issues with supports merging with the side and bumpers of the car leaving an underlining rectangle on a Rep clone)

Wreck_stacked3 also has an incomplete roof that should actual turn out well for you since the stubs can be filed down and the seats removed with little ease should u want a little hide-away space for miniatures or further conversion/bits.

Hi, I'm Mr. Piseeks, look at me!

This is a Raspberry Pi 3 case, based on the Meeseeks' Box, from "Rick and Morty". It is a 10cm cube, slightly bigger than the RPi. The side panel has the micro-USB, HDMI and jack ports at the bottom, while in the middle there is a hole for the GPIO pins. The rear (or front, it is up to you) has the "Ethernet+4USB" ports.

It's still a WIP, I'm deciding if modify it to make it fit the RPi leaving no room inside, or leave it as a cube (I'll probably make both).

My main idea is to print it, paint it and place a button on top of it, like the true Meeseeks' Box, and use it like a home-assistant (with the Google Kit released for the RPi) with the Mr. Meeseek voice.

Hi Guys
This is my take on the Jiangshi AR4 from Destiny. To start off this isn't an easy model, I really struggled to get the long thin parts to stop bending. My advice is don't put the long parts near any heat source until you've glued it all together. Maybe the PLA I used wasn't good enough, I don't know. Also it is very delicate when completed, very spindly and weak, the opposite that a real weapon would need to be to survive combat so I wouldn't use it for cosplay where it will get bashed about a lot. It's a display model really.
Happy to answer any questions and happy printing!
Check out my facebook page Bigbangcollectables for more cool models

SERVO MODELING SPHERES
Ian Gonsher
http://gonsherdesign.com/

These “modeling spheres” are designed to be simple design primitives that can be easily configured for easy prototyping with servos. Rather than beginning the design process with the hardware – in this case DXW90 MicroServo – modeling spheres allow makers and designers to begin by thinking about the kind of rotational motion they want to explore in their project. These elements can be easily combined in CAD to create more complicated forms, including XYZ axis robotic arms and mechanical locomotion. They are designed to be “print and play”. The servo arms simply slide and lock into place, with no additional hardware or glue (although it is recommended to trim the servo arm as shown in the picture).

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9hWgXtvLaSQ

description.text:
This is a cap/cover to prevent crossover from other instruments. It is used together with the shockmount I produced earlier (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2567703). During the recording of my bigband it became obvious that the percussion microphone (for conga's, shaker etc.) was getting to much unwanted sound from the drums and horns. So I developed this cap to shield it. On the inside I put some felt, but you could also use foam.

I did not think about publishing it until I printed it, so the OpenSCAD file is in Dutch. But it is not that difficult, so adaptions should be easy.

description.text:
This is an untested model, not printed it yet so wont share all files till i have proven them..

Box is H86mm W41mm D42mm approx.
510 is slightly recessed for flusher finish and designed to fit the Varitube 22mm 510.

You can choose to either print the battery sled and use dual 18650 for a DNA133/167 or you can fit a VT200 1300mAh Lipo for the full 200/250w depending which board you fit.
There is room inside the mod for the balance board plug, use an XT30 plug as an XT60 WILL NOT FIT.
The battery sled is designed for use with clip on keystone tabs as used on MosMax IMX Series Trays from Stealthvape.

comments.text: Yes, the Da Vinci Mini W only supports PLA, ive several models printed and working fine, though be careful not to run anything too hot as the PLA can soften and melt, i made one box for a friend who was dry firing an RDA and he said the box melted around the 510, though ive not seen it and dont know what the build in the RDA was, i have a squonker running at 80w and the RDA gets very toasty and so far the box is holding up well after two weeks.

description.text: a simple Hello KItty model
You have only to glue the parts together
you can make educational rotary engine!

Puzzle pieces with always the same tooth, but a varying tolerance on the opening.
9 pieces form one circle.
If you need more or less, you could always test your luck and ask (I've included the Autodesk Inventor file too)
I found that the 0.1mm variant fits best, provided you use the appropriate/good flow% for each filament.

In the picture you'll see all pieces with 0.1mm tolerance.

Colors used - in full, or with a mix:

  • Black
  • Blue
  • Yellow
  • White
  • Clear (or pearl if you want)

On the mixed white and black pieces I used the ironing option of Cura (3.0.4) - it's pretty cool in fact, leaving you with a pretty smooth surface!

I got the idea from these educational icon included in the pictures, but had no reason to execute it until I came across a print that I needed to split into 2 parts, as it was too big for my printsurface. So I wanted to split that and 'puzzle' it back together afterwards.
Question was: what gap should I leave - if any - after cutting the piece up?

Although I never really played this game ($.50 was a lot of money back then) I would, nonetheless, marvel at the art (By Don Bluth) every time I was at the arcade.

Each part is broken into color groups. I used beige, yellow, brown, red, and a flesh colored filament. Or you can just paint it.

He measures out at about 160mm tall.

I've built supports into the few parts that need them.

No lady should walk the woods unprepared for conflict. The Thingiverse version will last you through a quick jaunt to the Renaissance Faire, but if you really want to wow the wenches or bring the jarls to the yard you'll want a bronze or gold set from Shapeways: http://bit.ly/NafZaL They're more elegant and durable than their ABS-printed counterparts.

Just print and coif, though it wouldn't hurt to brush the shafts with sandpaper before milady puts these in her hair. Flagrant stagecraft alert: The lovely and talented Mrs. Zheng3 is modeling an earlier prototype, coated in gold leaf. The version you'll download is slightly thinner with a more effective taper. You can get an inexpensive (imitation) gold leaf kit off Amazon for a few bucks: http://amzn.to/PMiSil Here's a video tutorial on four ways to use hairsticks: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8YTFcq3N2v0&feature=related There are two STLs in the zip. The sprue version is for people having trouble with a long, skinny print: it adds a little surface area to keep the end of the stick from curling. Just trim it off with your preferred blade and sand the burrs. Print at high infill. See a lovely failure of this print at http://www.zheng3.com/2012/07/16/gossamer-failure/ Check for updates at http://www.zheng3.com, or http://www.twitter.com/Zheng3_Jim

title: LED defuser and holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A very basic LED light defuser that may be used for winter solstice (or insert your religion here) lights or just general fun. There are 5 holes for 3mm LED's in the base. The idea is to connect the LED's to a Raspberry PI to create various light patterns and effects.

A video clip of the LED's under control of a Raspberry Pi zero w may be found here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vRdY6kGnK24

Why 5 LED's? Common color's for LED's are red, blue, green, white and yellow. The first three are the primary colors so in theory, one can mix the light to get a spectrum of different colors. So this will hold one of each of the common LED's allowing one to play with different combinations.

The LED holes came out too small on an early iteration of this design despite the geometry of 3.1mm diameter. Depending on the calibration of your 3d printer, your results may vary.

I've used clear/natural PLA, but one could use any number of clear or translucent filaments could be used.

The Raspberry PI code is on github here:
https://github.com/mrncmoose/winter-solstice-lights

Enjoy!

Wanhao

Printer:

Duplicator 6

No

No

0.2

Infill:

Not needed

Notes:

The walls are very thin, so your settings for your printer and filament choice must be spot on.

title: Universal Spool Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A spool holder to fit multiple sizes of spools.
You will need 4 of 608 Ball Bearings to complete this Design.
4 M3 Bolts of length 25mm (Do not Exceed Dimensions Shown in Picture.)
4 M3 Hex Nuts

The Spool Roller and its shaft is designed to be an embedded print.

VERY IMPORTANT NOTE
Pay Attention to the order of printing.

Print the Bearing_Cover.stl File first.
Pause the print at height 9.2mm, Insert a 608 Bearing into the slot and finish printing.

Then Print the Bearing_Shaft.stl file.
Pause this print at height 13.5mm, Insert the Previous print into the shaft and resume printing.

You will not be able to assemble the bearing where its supposed to be otherwise.

Rest of the models can be printed in any order.

Improved design for the threaded half of the clamp file to allow for printing without supports.

01-02-2018.
Added new design of the roller pins that won't require pausing the print so you can print all of them in a single print. Its designed with low clearance so they cannot be removed again easily. To fit, print 2 and slide them into the bearing 1 from each side, use a soft mallet and knock them in. (Just 1 swing did the trick for me)

Printer:

MP Mini V2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.175

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I have used 100% infill for the bearing shaft and roller.

20% infill for all other parts.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed it upside down for a smooth top finish. I used supports for the phone slot and for the notches that click into the original bottom part.

description.text:
I had an old iPhone 5 docking station lying around ever since I went for the iPhone 6, years ago. It became useless because the slot where you placed the iPhone 5 was to narrow to fit any of the later models that has a case in place. I just didn’t like to take the case off every time.
As the lightning connector is still the same, it was actually too bad not to use such an expensive original Apple part. Therefore I designed this new top that fits over the existing bottom part which holds the lightning female and male connectors. The bottom has a aluminum bracket to add a counter weight to the docking station. I had to use a bench grinder to grind away a few millimeters so it would allow some extra space for phones with a case.

In the photo’s you’ll see the new printed top part on the left and the original iPhone 5 top on the right.

CTC Bizer

author: Stevetecx

description.text:
This is a multi cyclone I made to work as a pre-filter when cleaning the pool - and save a lot of water in the process - minimizing water needed for backwashing. Designed for fine particles. Works fine as filter for the shop vac too (remembering the fine particle part).

In the making of this I did a lot of reading-up on the function and math involved in these. The design parameters are by no means randomly selected. The result is an efficient and easy to print cyclone.

In order to separate all the fine particles out, high speed and low travel distance is needed. Achieving this combined with high volume throughput resulted in a setup with multiple combined cyclones.

See post print noted for assembly.

The nozzles are designed to fit pool and shop vac hoses. I you want to use it for a household vac you will need to make a reducer.

This multi cyclone is designed to be printed with no support.

2017.12.05: nozzle and manifold doesn't show in 3D thingiview. Fixed.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm or less

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Print:
1 x multi cyclone
1 x manifold
2 x nozzle

Post-printing

File of the blobs and seams to have a successful marriage between the cyclones and manifold.

You may want to break off one "tooth" on the nozzle to be mounted on the outlet manifold to have a good fit at the skew side. I keept all on mine though for better bond. Try and see what works for you.

Find an air/water tight bucket and makes some holes in the lid that matches the end of the funnels.

Insert funnels in the lid and make and glue it together with hot glue or silicone.

description.text:
This is the Bone Crown of Protection (+2) that I took of the corpse of the Ratling King who had invade Barrik's Keep. Any chance my DM will give me bonus experience points for realism? One can hope.

This is part of my continuing effort to learn how to use Meshmixer. I can see the power, but currently I am not even a level one wizard with the tools.

My biggest challenge is the beginning shape in meshmixer, so I've taken to building an outline with geometric shapes in Tinkercad and then working the shell in Meshmixer. I am very pleased with the outcome, and this crown stretches the limits of my printing bed. Double Level Up.
From an image found on internet, I designed the 3D model, exactly like my previous Dragon Shield.:https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2686467
My very first robot.

Pièce permettant de rendre le plus possible étanche la prise usb de la gopro Hero 5 avec utilisation du micro externe.
Pratiquant la moto, j'ai été obligé de retirer la trappe étanche de la gopro pour pouvoir utiliser un micro externe. J'ai donc créer cette pièce pour s'adapter autour du câble usb-c et ainsi se coller le plus possible au trou laissé par le vide de la trappe. Je peut maintenant rouler sans craindre la pluie. Je laisse aussi à disposition le fichier solidwork pour pouvoir l'adapter à d'autre câble usb (de la forme de celui de gopro par exemple).

édit (30/12/2017) : j'ai imperméabilisé la pièce avec du Plastimperm F10 et j'ai rouler sous pluie battante (j'en pleure encore ;) ) sans que ma caméra n'est pris l'eau.En retirant le câble usb aucune goutte d'eau n'était présente dans les environs de la trappe et la pièce ne s'est pas déformé avec la pluie (ni avec les U.V. depuis que je roule avec).

Supports act as spacers to fill in the gap between my plastic and the spool.  These supports provide for even tension for smooth dispensing.

I am printing 8 copies for each spool.  I have one spool for the one pound 11.5" bundle; the other spool is for the five pound 6" bundle.
I will insert the 8 pieces between the plastic and the inner diameter of the spool.

another type of sitting

The total cost of the machine at the time was about $700. This is a 21"x28"x28" (533mm x 711mm x 711mm) print area. You can see photos for some of the things I have printed. There are almost 500 hours of printing done on this printer. Some prints took over 48 hours to print.

The x/y axis on this machine is printed 100% from the C-bot design.

The Z axis is 100% custom and is where I was saving on the cost of the machine.The X-axis is placed on premium (much stronger/older wood) 2x4s. Everything was carefully measured to make certain it was square. Sometime I would have to use shims to make things perfectly square. The Z track is made from V channel and is what keeps the prints from z-banding because the bed is moved up and down by cheap 5/8 threaded rods.

This design was able to move up and down 35lbs of weight before it started to skip. Each corner has it's own threaded rod. The belt on the bottom is simply a triangle. The motors are attached to a center 2x4 that is at an angle. This helps because the motor can be moved up and down the board to get the tension close. Then fine tuning can be done by moving the motor in and out on the mount.

This is a Heated bed (crazy I know) and it is one of the fastest heating beds I've ever owned. And also the cheapest. So the heated bed is made from Tempered glass (free from the glass of a stove). I then purchased a toaster from a Thrift Store. I then tore apart and kapton taped the heater coils down to the bed evenly distributing the small and large coils throughout the bed. You must make sure never to allow a short to occur between two coils this will cause a fire!! Next I plugged that into a harbor freight router speed controller and turned it most of the way down. Next I turned off the lights and plugged it in. I slowly turned up the speed controller till it glowed or burned the kapton tape. I then turned it down as low as I was willing to go where it still produced heat. Then I put a opto isolated 120v relay up to the heat bed channel on the ramps board and then to the heat bed. I then taped two large silicone mats under the taped coils to keep the heat in. Next I used a cheap piece of steel to go on top of the heat bed. Then i purchased a clean piece of double strength annealed (don't do tempered, it flexes way too much) glass to go on top of that to print on. I then use hairspray for adhesion.

I used standard C-channel under the bed to build the support. this also used the screws on the corner to press it between the vertical V-channels to keep it straight.

It uses a ramps board with ocotoprint and a standard computer power supply. The gray wire from the power supply goes to ps_on to turn all the 12v stuff on or off. All wiring is done with network cable. The cable going to the hotend is high above the bed on purpose. Network cable cannot flex very much or it will break so by providing this long distance there is very little chance of that.

I added what STLs I could find I think I have some that got lost in fusion 360 maybe one day I can find them :-P

So this is V1 of my monster printer. I am posting this now because I am working to make a V2 with v-slot openbuilds track all cables with use keystone jacks. It will also be small enough and on wheel to slide under my workbench.

More to come. If you have questions let me know I will try to answer them as I can.

A hanging tea light holder, with holes for thread or fishing line.

Use of actual candles is not recommended. All photos were taken in a fully supervised environment.

This is the first in a series I call Robot-a-Week.

Every Sunday I will begin creating a robot design. By the end of the week it should be printed and posted.

Robot A

A simple blocky design with treads for feet.

Layout

Print Robot A's head rotated with his face on the build plate. I used the Hilbert Curve setting to give that pattern in the picture. The body is best printed on its side.
The feet (treads) need to be split in half for easier printing. This has already been done for the Complete file. The Feet file has not been split.
I did use supports on the head and feet (treads), but they should not be necessary. I was paranoid.

Robot-a-Week

Be sure to watch for the next robot in this series. I am using it to improve my Fusion 360 skills. Please leave any questions in the Comments. I'll do my best to answer them.
Also be sure to show off any robots you make from this series. I would love to see them.

Hopefully we can create a great robot army!

description.text:
This is supposed to be beginning of the screw and nut. Actually, it wasn´t so easy to realize functioning of the OPENSCAD and especially imagination of rotating polyhedrons. Right now we can just create teeth profile with polyhedron or other elementary forms in openscad and when we mend it rotate we have a thread.....

It is true, that my ten-core i7 intel has to process it (Krivky.scad) in cgal for 2 minutes smaller version and 17:41 minutes longer version.....

Following the post of Philipp Klostermann, I have started to analyze different approach. It is not so easy to imagine steps of computation with let statement so, this takes some time to modify initial post of Philipp Klostermann.in order to transform it into the equation of a helicoid.

So the result could be seen in "screw_extrude_EaVF.scad" file. This is a file of P. Klostermann streamlined to my needs. And if you want som I have find a library for threads downloadable on the http://dkprojects.net/openscad-threads/.
